Properties: Hydrosol; soluble in cold water; heating increases solubility.
Not soluble in oil or alcohol.
Dissolves in solutions containing less than 15% alcohol.
Water solubility: mixing ratio with water can be up to 60%.
Compared to other gums, which dissolve only about 5–8% in water before reaching saturation.
Notes:
Source and processing: Made from the dried sap (gum exudate) of Acacia senegal and Acacia seyal. Commercial products are dried into flakes and milled; some are spray-dried.

Usage: Primarily used in the food industry as a stabilizer and emulsifier.

Market note: Gum arabic is sometimes erroneously used as a substitute for tao jiao (桃膠), which is the secretion from the trunks of peach, plum, apricot, and cherry trees; it is reported that peach gum on the market is often replaced by gum arabic.

Name: xuan fu hua
Botanical: Inula britannica L. var. chinensis (Rupr.) Reg.
Inula britannica L. (歐亞旋覆花, 大花旋覆花)
Other name: jin fo hua (golden Buddha flower) 金佛花
jin fo cao (golden Buddha grass) 金佛草（江浙）
liu yue ju (Chrysanthemum of June) 六月菊（河北）
mao er duo (hairy ears) 毛耳朵
bai ye cao (hundred leaf grass) 百葉草

Maladies Treated: Wind-cold type cough (風寒咳嗽); part used: flower (Flos)
Phlegm retention and accumulation (痰飲蓄結); part used: flower (Flos)
Fullness in the chest and epigastrium (胸膈痞滿); part used: flower (Flos)
Asthmatic cough with abundant phlegm (喘咳痰多); part used: flower (Flos)
Vomiting (嘔吐); part used: flower (Flos)
Belching/burping (噫氣); part used: flower (Flos)
Lumps or hardness below the chest/‘hardness and fullness below the Heart’ (心下痞硬); part used: flower (Flos)
Dosage: 3–9 g; wrap in cloth to decoct (包煎).
Contraindications: Do not use in yinxu (yin deficiency) with chronic cough. Contraindicated for dry cough with wind-heat type syndrome (風熱燥咳).
Research:
Antibacterial: Using plate paper disk or ditch method tests, a 1:1 xuan fu hua (Flos Inulae) decoction showed significant inhibitory effects against Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus anthracis, and Shigella flexneri IIa strain. [a]

Anti-inflammatory: Anti-inflammatory activities of xuan fu hua extract might be attributed to the inhibition of NO, iNOS, and cytokine expression through down-regulation of NF-κB activation via suppression of IκBα and MAP kinase phosphorylation in macrophages. [5]

Inflorescence (Inula britannica L.): Quercetin 7-glucuronoglucoside (槲皮素7-葡萄糖醛酸葡萄糖甙)

Name: shan zhu yu
shan yu rou
Other name: Henan: rou zao (肉棗), yao zao (藥棗), zao pi (棗皮), shi zao (實棗)

Geography: Cornus officinalis Sieb. et Zucc.: middle and southern parts of China (华南, 华中)
Maladies Treated: Hypertension
Impotence
Spermatorrhea
Instant sweating
Sore or weak knees
Chronic lower back pain
Frequent urination
Incontinence
Excessive bleeding during menstrual periods
Bleeding from uterus
Tinnitus
Bed wetting (enuresis)
Sweating non stop
Priapism due to yinxu condition: kidney yin deficiency with hyperactive deficient fire causing the yang organ to be easily aroused
Excessive bleeding during menopause due to liver and kidney yin deficiency
Premature ejaculation, impotence, spermatorrhea due to yinxu condition
Night sweating due to yinxu condition
Dizziness and decreased vision due to liver deficiency and kidney yin deficiency
Dosage: Normal usage is 5 to 10 g. Large dosage can up to 30 g.
Samples of Formulae:
Bed wetting (enuresis): Shan zhu yu (Cornus fruit) 15 g, Fu pen zi (Chinese raspberry fruit) 15 g, Yi zhi ren (Alpinia fruit) 11 g, Tu si zi (Cuscuta seed) 11 g, Xian mao (Curculigo rhizome) 11 g. Boil with water and drink as tea.

Sweating non stop: Shan zhu yu (Cornus fruit) 15 g, Wu wei zi (Schisandra fruit) 9 g, raw Long gu (Dragon bone) 30 g, raw Mu li (Oyster shell) 30 g. Boil with water and make into 3 servings.

Priapism due to yinxu condition (kidney yin deficiency with hyperactive deficient fire causing easy arousal): Shu di huang (Prepared Rehmannia root) 30 g, Shan yu rou (Cornus fruit) 15 g, Gui ban (Tortoise plastron) 15 g, Bie jia (Soft-shelled turtle shell) 15 g, Huang bai (Phellodendron bark) 15 g, Zhi mu (Anemarrhena rhizome) 12 g. Boil with water and make into 2 servings.

Excessive bleeding during menopause due to liver and kidney yin deficiency: Shu di huang (Prepared Rehmannia root) 24 g, Shan yao (Chinese yam rhizome) 15 g, Shan zhu yu (Cornus fruit) 15 g, Dang gui (Angelica sinensis root) 12 g, Bai shao (White peony root) 12 g, Dan pi (Moutan cortex) 12 g, Fu ling (Poria) 9 g, Ze xie (Alisma rhizome) 9 g, Ai ye (Mugwort leaf) 9 g, Xi cao (Madder root) 9 g, Di yu (Sanguisorba root) 9 g, Han lian cao (Eclipta herb) 9 g. Boil with water. Make into 3 servings.

Premature ejaculation, impotence, spermatorrhea due to yinxu condition: Shu di huang (Prepared Rehmannia root) 30 g, Shan zhu yu (Cornus fruit) 30 g, Jin ying zi (Cherokee rose fruit) 15 g, Zhi mu (Anemarrhena rhizome) 12 g, Huang bai (Phellodendron bark) 12 g. Boil with water. Make into 2 servings for morning and night.

Night sweating due to yinxu condition: Shan zhu yu (Cornus fruit) 30 g, Mai dong (Ophiopogon root) 18 g, Sheng di huang (Raw Rehmannia root) 24 g, Wu wei zi (Schisandra fruit) 9 g. Boil with water. Use as tea.

Dizziness and decreased vision due to liver deficiency and kidney yin deficiency: Shan zhu yu (Cornus fruit) 30 g, Gou qi zi (Goji berry) 30 g, Shu di huang (Prepared Rehmannia root) 24 g, Ju hua (Chrysanthemum flower) 15 g. Boil with water and divide into 2 servings. Source: 中醫藥報, 陳國華.
Contraindications:
Not to use in cases of liver yang ascending and in cases of difficulty in urination due to damp-heat.
According to the Whole Nation of Japan Farmers' Federation, five kinds of Chinese herb being sold in the market—chen pi, su ye, da zao, jie shi, shan zhu yu—were tested and showed they contain six kinds of farm chemical residues; among them chen pi had the highest content. Although there is a suspicion of conflict of interest, the credibility is high. It is better to soak the herb in water and wash it thoroughly before use.

Name: zong lu pi
Common: leaf sheath fibres of fortune windmill palm

Maladies Treated: Hematemesis (吐血).
Epistaxis (衄血).
Blood in stool (便血).
Xue lin (血淋) hematuria due to urinary tract infection such as cystitis, pyelonephritis, urethritis causing bloody urine.
Uterine bleeding/menorrhagia or metrorrhagia (血崩).
External traumatic bleeding (外傷出血).
Persistent nosebleed: zong lu (棕櫚) ash blown into the bleeding nostril.
Chronic nosebleed not stopping: zong lu (棕櫚), ci ji (刺薊, thistle), hua shu pi (樺樹皮, birch bark), long gu (龍骨, dragon bone) in equal parts, powdered; 2 qian (~7.5 g) each dose with cooked rice water.

Heavy uterine bleeding with near collapse (婦人崩中，下血數升，氣欲絕): zong tong (棕桐) 3 liang burned to ash, zi shen (紫參), she xiang (麝香, musk) finely ground, fu long gan (伏龍肝, stove-ash/calcined yellow clay); 2 qian per dose with hot wine, timing not restricted.
Uterine bleeding: zong lu pi (棕櫚皮) charred, fine powder 1 qian, mu li (牡蠣, oyster shell; calcined) 0.5 qian, a little she xiang (musk), taken with rice drink on an empty stomach.
Unstoppable uterine bleeding: zong lu pi (棕櫚皮) charred to preserve nature, formed into bundles; 3 qian taken with light wine on an empty stomach.
Menstrual bleeding not stopping: zong lu pi (棕櫚皮) burned to ash and bai ye (柏葉, Chinese arborvitae leaf; roasted) 1 liang each; powdered; 2 qian with wine.

Red and white vaginal discharge, beng-lou (崩漏), prolonged cold of fetal qi with periumbilical pain: zong mao (棕毛, palm fibers) charred and pu huang (蒲黃, cattail pollen; fried) in equal parts; 3 qian per dose with good wine, on an empty stomach before meals, twice daily.

Pregnancy with fetal restlessness, bleeding not stopping, periumbilical pain: zong lu pi (棕櫚皮) burned to ash, yuan can sha (原蠶沙, silkworm feces; roasted) 1 liang each, e jiao (阿膠, donkey-hide gelatin; dry-fried) 3 fen; 2 qian spoon each dose with warm wine.

Intestinal wind diarrhea with blood (腸風瀉血): zong lu (棕櫚) ash 2 liang and shu ai (熟艾, prepared mugwort) 1 liang mashed with two cooked chicken eggs; separately, pao fu zi (炮附子, prepared aconite) 1 qian in one cup of water brought to a boil then cooled; mix in 2 qian of the first preparation (~3 g) and take on an empty stomach.
Shui gu li xia (水谷痢下) dysentery: zong lu pi (棕櫚皮) burned and ground; 1 fangcunbi (~1 g) with water.
Persistent xue lin (血淋不止) hematuria: zong lu pi (棕櫚皮) half burned, half dry-fried to powder; 2 qian per dose.
Urinary retention (小便不通): palm bark hairs (棕樹皮毛) burned to ash preserving nature; 2 qian taken with water and wine.
Hypertension (高血壓): fresh zong lu pi (鮮棕櫚皮) 6 qian and fresh sunflower receptacle (鮮向日葵花盤) 2 liang; decocted in water; one dose daily.
Dosage: Internal: decoction 10–15 g. External: appropriate amount, ground to powder for topical application.

Maladies Treated: Convulsions (驚風抽搐)
Epilepsy (癲癎)
Stroke (中風)
Hemiplegia (半身不遂)
Mouth and eye deviation/facial paralysis (口眼喎斜)
Migraine (偏頭痛)
Arthritis pain / rheumatic bi pain (風濕痺痛)
Tetanus (破傷風)
Tuberculosis of lymph nodes (淋巴結結核)
Urticaria (風疹)
Furuncles/sores and swellings (瘡腫)
Cervical cancer (used within a multi-herb internal and local regimen as detailed in Samples of Formulae)
Medical Function: Analgesic effect (tail more potent than body)
Cardiovascular modulation: increases cardiac contractility and slows heart rate
Enhances papillary muscle contraction; induces aortic contraction via Ca2+ pathway activation
Bidirectional immunomodulation helping maintain immune system balance
Samples of Formulae:
For cervical cancer: Internal formula — Lu Feng Fang (Vespa nest) 9 g, Quan Xie (Scorpion) 9 g, Shui Zhi (Leech) 6 g, Meng Chong (Horsefly) 6 g, Zhi Ru Xiang (Prepared frankincense) 6 g, Zhi Mo Yao (Prepared myrrh) 6 g, Huang Lian (Coptis rhizome) 6 g, Huang Bai (Phellodendron bark) 6 g, Mu Dan Pi (Moutan cortex) 12 g, Long Dan Cao (Gentiana) 15 g. Grind all evenly. Use Jin Yin Hua (Honeysuckle flower) 3 g decocted to prepare the liquid; use it to form Yu Huang Dan–type pills, mung-bean size, coated with Xiong Huang (Realgar). Take 1.5 g per dose, twice daily, with warm water.
Local application — Gong Jing San (cervical powder): She Xiang (Musk) 1.2 g, She Chuang Zi (Cnidium fruit) 4.2 g, Xue Jie (Dragon's blood) 7.5 g, Mo Yao (Myrrh) 9 g, Ru Xiang (Frankincense) 10.5 g, Er Cha (Catechu) 10.5 g, Bing Pian (Borneol) 10.5 g, Peng Sha (Borax) 10.5 g, Nao Sha (Natron) 10.5 g, Zhong Ru Shi (Stalactite/calcite) 13.2 g, Xiong Huang (Realgar) 13.2 g, Qian Dan (Minium/lead oxide) 46.5 g, Bai Fan (Alum) 285 g. Grind to fine powder. Apply an appropriate amount to the cervix twice per week.
Course: Combine internal and local treatments continuously for 6 months. Observed outcomes: leucorrhea decreased and bleeding stopped. Continued therapy until gynecological re-examination showed lesion disappearance and a smooth cervix.
Contraindications: Toxic dosage: 30–60 g. Toxic components include neurotoxin, hemolytic toxin (溶血毒素), bleeding toxin (出血毒素), and cardiovascular vasoconstricting toxin (心血管收縮毒素). Allergic reactions may occur in some individuals, presenting with rash and urticaria (hives), possibly accompanied by fever.
Research:
Compound in scorpion venom and periodontal bone loss: A compound found in scorpion venom inhibited bone loss in an animal model of advanced periodontal disease. A Harvard University report noted that in rats with periodontitis, Kalitoxin led to an 84% reduction of mandibular bone loss within 10 days without fatal side effects such as heart disease or kidney problems. The report suggested potential applicability to periodontal disease involving jawbone, arthritis, or osteoporosis. [1]
Central nervous system effects — anti-convulsion: Quan xie powder or its decoction showed anti-convulsant effects in mice. Intravenous injection of 0.28 mg/kg of a pure polypeptide separated from scorpion venom (anti-epilepsy peptide; also referred to as katsutoxin) markedly inhibited caffeine-induced convulsions in mice.
Central nervous system effects — anti-epilepsy: Katsutoxin and an anti-epilepsy peptide both prolonged the latency (hibernation period) of epilepsy induced by cephalosporins compared to control, reduced the intensity of attacks, and shortened the duration; the anti-epilepsy peptide had a stronger effect, required a smaller dose, and had lower toxicity.
Analgesic effects: The tail of the scorpion produced an analgesic effect approximately 5 times stronger than the scorpion body; scorpion venom showed strong analgesic action across different pain types.
Cardiovascular effects: After perfusion with 50 μg/0.1 ml of scorpion venom, isolated guinea pig hearts exhibited a significant increase in myocardial contraction force along with a decreased heart rate. Scorpion venom enhanced contraction of rabbit papillary muscles and induced contraction of aortic strips, effects associated with activation of cellular Ca2+ channels and increased membrane permeability to Ca2+.
Hematologic/oncologic and immune effects: Quan xie exhibited anti-thrombotic effects and anti-tumor effects. Scorpion proteins demonstrated bidirectional regulation of the human immune system, maintaining immune balance.
Notes: Character note: In 多胜肽, the character 胜 is not a simplified form of 勝; 胜 is pronounced shēng (sheng1). In mainland China, 多胜肽 is written as 多肽, possibly to avoid reading 胜 as 勝.

Scorpion venom: Katsutoxin (a protein toxin with neurotoxicity second only to snake neurotoxins)
Phospholipase A2 (also referred to as hemolysin)
Whole scorpion (quan xie) hydrolysate: Multiple amino acids required by the human body (produced via hydrolysis)
29 inorganic elements, with especially high levels of magnesium, calcium, and zinc

Pharmaceutical name:英文藥名﹕Buthus martensiLatin  name:拉丁學名﹕Buthus martensii  Karsch.Pron. in Japanese:日語發音 ﹕zenkatsuPron. in Korean:韓語發音 ﹕chonholPron. in Cantonese:粵音﹕cyun4 hit3Other Names:別名 ﹕chai kui 蠆 奎， chai chong 蠆尾虫，du bo  杜伯， zhu bu chong 主簿虫，quan chong  全虫， fu bei chong 茯背虫。Common Name:英文名﹕scorpion, buthusDistribution:產地﹕Henan, Shandong, Hebei, Liaoning, Anhui, Hubei.河南，山東，河北，遼寧，湖北等省。Properties(characteristics)﹕性味﹕neutral, acrid, sweet, toxic.性平，味辛。甘，有毒。Channels (meridians) entered: 歸經﹕liver肝Medical functions:藥理﹕ 
      A compound found in scorpion venom has inhibited bone loss in an animal 
      model of advanced periodontal disease.[1] Effect on CNS: (1) anti-convulsion:quan xie powder or its decoction possesses anti-convulsion effect on mice. Intra venous injection of 0.28mg/kg with pure polypeptide separated from the scorpion (quan xie) katsutoxin, can inhibit the convulsion effect of mice caused by caffeine. (2) ani-epilepsy katsutoxin and anti-epilepsy peptide can both prolong the hibernation period of epilepsy caused by Cephalosporins, compared to control group. The flare up is less intense, and the period is shorter. The anti-epilepsy peptide effect is strong, dosage is small and toxicity is low.  (3) analgesic effect: the tail of xie (scorpion) is 5 times stronger than the body of xie (scorpion). Katsutoxin possesses a strong analgesic effect of different type of pain. Effect on circulatory system: after injecting 50μg/0.1ml of katsutoxin, the quinea pigs' cardiac muscles showed stronger contraction strength and slowed down the heart rate. Katsutoxin can improve papilla muscles of rabbits and cause contraction of the aorta and this may caused by activating the Ca2+ pathway, increasing the the permeability of Ca2+. Effect of anti thrombosis Effect of anti-tumor Xie (scorpion) possesses the immune system adjustmen in both directions. It can maintain the balance of human immune system. 蠍毒蠍毒的其中化合物有防止 患牙周病老 鼠的 牙床骨頭退化。對中樞神經系統的作用 ①抗驚厥：全蠍粉末或提取物對小鼠有抗驚厥作用，小鼠靜脈注射由蠍毒分離出的 純 品多 胜肽-抗癲 癇肽0.28mg/kg對咖啡因引起的驚厥有明顯的抑制作用。②抗癲癇蠍毒 和抗癲癇肽均使頭孢菌素引起癲癇的潛伏期比對照組延長，發作程度 減輕，持續時間縮短；抗癲癇肽的作用強。用量小。毒性低。③鎮痛蠍尾的鎮痛作 用比蠍身強約5倍；蠍毒對各類疼痛均有很強的鎮痛作用。對心血管系統的作用 灌注蠍毒50μg/0.1ml後可使離體豚鼠心臟心肌收縮力明顯增強，同時引起 心率減慢。蠍毒能增加兔乳頭肌收縮力和引起主動脈條收縮，與其激活細胞Ca2+通道。增加膜對Ca2+的通透性有關。全蠍具有抗血栓。全蠍具有抗 腫瘤作用。蠍蛋白可以雙向調節人體免疫系統，維護人體免疫系統的平衡。Actions & Indications:主治﹕Being used in epilepsy, stroke, paralysis, migraine, pain in arthritis, tetanus, tuberculosis in lymph nodes, urticaria, and bunacles.治驚風抽搐。癲癎。中風。半身不遂。口 眼喎斜。偏頭痛。風濕痺痛。破傷風。淋巴結結核。風疹瘡腫。Chemical ingredients:化學成份﹕Contains katsutoxin, a toxin which is only less toxic to the neurotoxin of poisonous snakes. katsutoxin composes of different toxin, including insect neurotoxin, beetle neurotoxin, mammal neurotoxon, polypetides that possess anti-epilepsy property, pain inhibiting polypeptides like tityustoxin, hyaluronidase, hemolysin. Hydrolysis of quan xie (whole scorpion) can produce many kind of amino acid which the human body required. It also contain 29 kinds of inorganic elements, especially high in magnesium, calcium, and zinc. It also contain taurine, palmitic acid, stearic acid, cholesterol, lecithin, katsu acid, trimethylamine, and betaine etc.主含蠍毒(katsutoxin)，是一類毒性僅次於蛇毒神經毒的蛋白質。蠍 毒中含多種蠍毒素，包括昆虫類神經毒素，甲殼類神經毒素，哺乳動物神經毒素，抗癲癇活性的多胜肽polypeptides)， 鎮痛活性多肽如蠍毒素(tityustoxin)，透明質酸酶(hyaluronidase) ，磷脂酶A2(又稱溶血素) 。全蠍水解液含多種氨基 酸(為人體必須氨基酸) 。並含29種無機元素，尤其以鎂。鈣 。鋅的含量為多。此外尚含牛磺酸(taurine)  。軟脂酸(palmitic acid)  。硬脂酸(stearic acid) 。膽甾醇(cholesterol) 。卵磷脂(lecithin) 。蠍酸(katsu acid)  。三甲胺 (trimethylamine) 。甜菜鹼(betaine) 等成分。註；多胜
      肽的『 胜』字不是『勝』字的减筆字。『 胜』讀做生(sheng1)。在中國大陸，『多胜肽 』寫作『多肽』，可能為了避免把胜字 當作勝字念。Dosage:用量﹕3～9gSamples of formulae:處方舉例﹕wen dan fang 溫膽湯宮頸癌： 露蜂房、全蠍各9克，水蛭、虻虫、制乳香、制沒藥、黃連、黃柏各6克，牡丹皮12克，龍膽草15克 共研勻，用銀花3克煎湯，泛制為愈黃丹， 丸如綠 豆大，雄黃為衣，每服1.5克，日服2次，溫開水送服。局部用宮頸散：麝香1.2克，蛇床子4.2克，血竭7.5克，沒藥9 克，乳香、兒茶、冰片 、硼砂、硇砂各10.5克，鐘乳石、雄黃各13.2克，鉛丹46.5克，白礬285克 共研末，為宮頸散，每用適量，塗 敷 宮頸，每周 2次。如此內服 外塗 ，連續6個月，白帶減少，出血停止。繼續至婦科復查，病灶消失，宮頸光滑。  Modern Research:現代研究﹕According to a report from Harvard University a 
      compound found in scorpion venom has inhibited bone loss in an animal 
      model of advanced periodontal disease.[1]  哈佛大學一項研究發現， 蠍子毒液中的一種成分Kalitoxin讓患有 牙周病骨質損失的老 鼠，在10天內，減少84%的下顎骨質損失，而且這些老鼠並沒有因毒液而發生致命的副作用，例如心臟病或腎臟問題。Kalitoxin 可能有助治療下顎骨引起的牙周病。關節炎或骨質疏鬆症。Toxicity & Cautions:毒素與禁忌﹕Toxic dosage is 30 to 60 g.
